an6.42:4.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins called Icchānaṅgala.
an6.42:4.3: He stayed on in a forest near Icchānaṅgala.
an6.42:4.4: The brahmins and householders of Venāgapura heard:
an6.42:4.5: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Icchānaṅgala. He is staying in a forest near Icchānaṅgala.
an6.42:4.7: ‘That Blessed One is perfect, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of people, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
an6.42:4.9: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others. He teaches Dharma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased; and he explains a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an6.42:4.10: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
an6.42:4.11: Then, when the night had passed, they took many different foods and went to the forest near Icchānaṅgala,
an6.42:4.12: where they stood outside the gates making a dreadful racket.
an6.42:5.1: Now, at that time Venerable Nāgita was the Buddha’s attendant.
an6.42:5.2: Then the Buddha said to Nāgita:
an6.42:5.3: “Nāgita, who’s making that dreadful racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”
an6.42:5.4: “Sir, it’s these brahmins and householders of Icchānaṅgala. They’ve brought many different foods, and they’re standing outside the gates wanting to offer it specially to the Buddha and the mendicant Saṅgha.”
an6.42:5.5: “Nāgita, may I never become famous. May fame not come to me.
an6.42:5.6: There are those who can’t get the bliss of renunciation, the bliss of seclusion, the bliss of peace, the bliss of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty like I can. Let them enjoy the filthy, lazy pleasure of possessions, honor, and popularity.”
an6.42:6.1: “Sir, may the Blessed One please relent now! May the Holy One relent!
an6.42:6.3: Now is the time for the Buddha to relent.
an6.42:6.4: Wherever the Buddha now goes, the brahmins and householders will incline the same way, as will the people of town and country.
an6.42:6.5: It’s like when it rains heavily and the water flows downhill.
an6.42:6.6: In the same way, wherever the Buddha now goes, the brahmins and householders will incline the same way, as will the people of town and country.
an6.42:6.8: Because of the Buddha’s ethics and wisdom.”
an6.42:7.1: “Nāgita, may I never become famous. May fame not come to me.
an6.42:7.2: There are those who can’t get the bliss of renunciation, the bliss of seclusion, the bliss of peace, the bliss of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty like I can. Let them enjoy the filthy, lazy pleasure of possessions, honor, and popularity.
an6.42:8.1: Take a mendicant living in a village district who I see sitting in samadhi.
an6.42:8.3: ‘Now a monastery worker, a novice, or a fellow practitioner will make this venerable fall from samādhi.’
an6.42:8.4: So I’m not pleased that that mendicant is living in a village district.
an6.42:9.1: Take a mendicant in the wilderness who I see sitting nodding in meditation.
an6.42:9.3: ‘Now this venerable, having dispelled that sleepiness and weariness, will focus just on the unified perception of wilderness.’
an6.42:9.4: So I’m pleased that that mendicant is living in the wilderness.
an6.42:10.1: Take a mendicant in the wilderness who I see sitting without meditative samādhi.
an6.42:10.3: ‘Now this venerable will unify the mind in not unified in samādhi or preserve the mind already unified in samādhi.’
an6.42:10.4: So I’m pleased that that mendicant is living in the wilderness.
an6.42:11.1: Take a mendicant in the wilderness who I see sitting in samādhi.
an6.42:11.3: ‘Now this venerable will free the unfreed mind or preserve the freed mind.’
an6.42:11.4: So I’m pleased that that mendicant is living in the wilderness.
an6.42:12.1: Take a mendicant who I see living in a village district receiving robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
an6.42:12.2: Enjoying possessions, honor, and popularity they neglect solitude, and they neglect remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.
an6.42:12.3: They come down to villages, towns and capital cities and make their homes there.
an6.42:12.4: So I’m not pleased that that mendicant is living in a village district.
an6.42:13.1: Take a mendicant who I see in the wilderness receiving robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
an6.42:13.2: Fending off possessions, honor, and popularity they don’t neglect solitude, and they don’t neglect remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.
an6.42:13.3: So I’m pleased that that mendicant is living in the wilderness.
an6.42:14.1: Nāgita, when I’m walking along a road and I don’t see anyone ahead or behind I feel relaxed, even if I need to urinate or defecate.”
